<div class="byline">

<p class="author-role" data-aid="159163124" id="author2">Of the Quorum of the Twelve Apostles</p>

<p class="kicker" data-aid="159163129" id="kicker1">Words set a tone. They voice our thoughts, feelings, and experiences, for good or bad.</p>
</header>
<div class="body-block">
<p data-aid="159163133" id="p1">Brothers, sisters, and friends across the world, I am honored to address this vast audience, many of whom are members of our Church and many of whom are friends and new listeners to this conference broadcast. Welcome!</p>
<p data-aid="159163139" id="p2">The messages shared from this pulpit are communicated in words. They are given in English and translated into nearly 100 different languages. Always the base is the same. Words. And words matter a lot. Let me say that again. Words matter!</p>
<p data-aid="159163145" id="p3">They are the bedrock of how we connect; they represent our beliefs, morals, and perspectives. Sometimes we speak words; other times we listen. Words set a tone. They voice our thoughts, feelings, and experiences, for good or bad.</p>
<p data-aid="159163151" id="p4">Unfortunately, words can be thoughtless, hasty, and hurtful. Once said, we cannot take them back. They can wound, punish, cut down, and even lead to destructive actions. They can weigh heavily on us.</p>
<p data-aid="159163157" id="p5">On the other hand, words can celebrate victory, be hopeful and encouraging. They can prompt us to rethink, reboot, and redirect our course. Words can open our minds to truth.</p>
<p data-aid="159163164" id="p6">That is why, first and foremost, the Lord’s words matter.</p>
<p data-aid="159163171" id="p7">In the Book of Mormon, the prophet Alma and his people in ancient America encountered endless warfare with those who had disregarded the word of God, hardened their hearts, and corrupted their culture. The faithful could have fought, but Alma counseled: “And now, as the preaching of the word had a great tendency to lead the people to do that which was just—yea, it had had more powerful effect upon the minds of the people than the sword, or anything else, which had happened unto them—therefore Alma thought it was expedient that they should try the virtue of the word of God.”<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/41rasband?lang=eng#note1" data-scroll-id="note1"><sup class="marker" data-value="1"></sup></a></p>
<p data-aid="159163177" id="p9">The “word of God” surpasses all other expressions. It has been so since the Creation of the earth when the Lord spoke: “Let there be light: and there was light.”<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/41rasband?lang=eng#note2" data-scroll-id="note2"><sup class="marker" data-value="2"></sup></a></p>
<p data-aid="159163184" id="p10">From the Savior came these assurances in the New Testament: “Heaven and earth shall pass away, but my words shall not pass away.”<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/41rasband?lang=eng#note3" data-scroll-id="note3"><sup class="marker" data-value="3"></sup></a></p>
<p data-aid="159163190" id="p11">And this: “If a man love me, he will keep my words: and my Father will love him, and we will come unto him, and make our abode with him.”<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/41rasband?lang=eng#note4" data-scroll-id="note4"><sup class="marker" data-value="4"></sup></a></p>
<p data-aid="159163197" id="p12">And from Mary, the mother of Jesus, came this humble testimony: “Behold the handmaid of the Lord; be it unto me according to thy word.”<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/41rasband?lang=eng#note5" data-scroll-id="note5"><sup class="marker" data-value="5"></sup></a></p>
<p data-aid="159163202" id="p13">Believing and heeding the word of God will draw us closer to Him. President Russell M. Nelson has promised, “If you will study His words, your ability to be more like Him will increase.”<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/41rasband?lang=eng#note6" data-scroll-id="note6"><sup class="marker" data-value="6"></sup></a></p>
<p data-aid="159163210" id="p14">Don’t we all want to be, as the hymn says, “more blessed and holy—more, Savior, like thee”?<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/41rasband?lang=eng#note7" data-scroll-id="note7"><sup class="marker" data-value="7"></sup></a></p>
<p data-aid="159163216" id="p15">I picture young Joseph Smith on his knees hearing the words of his Father in Heaven: “[Joseph,] This is My Beloved Son. Hear Him!”<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/41rasband?lang=eng#note8" data-scroll-id="note8"><sup class="marker" data-value="8"></sup></a></p>
<p data-aid="159163223" id="p16">We “hear Him” in the words of scripture, but do we let them just sit on the page, or do we recognize He is speaking to us? Do we change?</p>
<span class="page-break" data-page="75"></span>
<p data-aid="159163229" id="p17">We “hear Him” in personal revelation and promptings from the Holy Ghost, in answers to prayer, and in those moments when only Jesus Christ, through the power of His Atonement, can lift our burdens, grant us forgiveness and peace, and embrace us “in the arms of his love.”<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/41rasband?lang=eng#note9" data-scroll-id="note9"><sup class="marker" data-value="9"></sup></a></p>
<p data-aid="159163235" id="p18">Second, the words of prophets matter.</p>
<p data-aid="159163242" id="p19">Prophets testify of the divinity of Jesus Christ. They teach His gospel and show His love for all.<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/41rasband?lang=eng#note10" data-scroll-id="note10"><sup class="marker" data-value="10"></sup></a> I bear my witness that our living prophet, President Russell M. Nelson, hears and speaks the word of the Lord.</p>
<p data-aid="159163246" id="p20">President Nelson has a way with words. He has said, “Keep on the covenant path,”<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/41rasband?lang=eng#note11" data-scroll-id="note11"><sup class="marker" data-value="11"></sup></a> “Gather Israel,”<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/41rasband?lang=eng#note12" data-scroll-id="note12"><sup class="marker" data-value="12"></sup></a> “Let God prevail,”<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/41rasband?lang=eng#note13" data-scroll-id="note13"><sup class="marker" data-value="13"></sup></a> “Build bridges of understanding,”<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/41rasband?lang=eng#note14" data-scroll-id="note14"><sup class="marker" data-value="14"></sup></a> “Give thanks,”<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/41rasband?lang=eng#note15" data-scroll-id="note15"><sup class="marker" data-value="15"></sup></a> “Increase your faith in Jesus Christ,”<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/41rasband?lang=eng#note16" data-scroll-id="note16"><sup class="marker" data-value="16"></sup></a> “Take charge of your testimony,”<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/41rasband?lang=eng#note17" data-scroll-id="note17"><sup class="marker" data-value="17"></sup></a> and “Become a peacemaker.”<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/41rasband?lang=eng#note18" data-scroll-id="note18"><sup class="marker" data-value="18"></sup></a></p>
<p data-aid="159163252" id="p21">Most recently, he has asked us to “think celestial.” “When you are confronted with a dilemma,” he said, “think celestial! When tested by temptation, think celestial! When life or loved ones let you down, think celestial! When someone dies prematurely, think celestial. … When the pressures of life crowd in upon you, think celestial! … As you think celestial, your heart will gradually change, … you will view trials and opposition in a new light, … [and] your faith will increase.”<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/41rasband?lang=eng#note19" data-scroll-id="note19"><sup class="marker" data-value="19"></sup></a></p>
<p data-aid="159163258" id="p22">When we think celestial, we see “things as they really are, and … really will be.”<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/41rasband?lang=eng#note20" data-scroll-id="note20"><sup class="marker" data-value="20"></sup></a> In this world burdened with confusion and contention, we all need that perspective.</p>
<p data-aid="159163266" id="p23">Elder George Albert Smith, long before becoming President of the Church, spoke of sustaining the prophet and heeding his words. He said: “The obligation that we make when we raise our hands … is a most sacred one. … It means … that we will stand behind him; we will pray for him; … and we will strive to carry out his instructions as the Lord shall direct.”<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/41rasband?lang=eng#note21" data-scroll-id="note21"><sup class="marker" data-value="21"></sup></a> In other words, we will diligently act upon our prophet’s words.</p>
<p data-aid="159163272" id="p24">As one of 15 prophets, seers, and revelators sustained yesterday by our worldwide Church, I want to share with you one of my experiences sustaining the prophet and embracing his words. It was for me much like the prophet Jacob, who recounted, “I had heard the voice of the Lord speaking unto me in very word.”<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/41rasband?lang=eng#note22" data-scroll-id="note22"><sup class="marker" data-value="22"></sup></a></p>
<div><div class="imageWrapper-wTPPD"><figure class="imageWithModal-ILaMF loadImageItem-u5D4D" title="Elder and Sister Rasband in Thailand."><img width="500" height="729" alt=""/><div class="container-W4jed"><div class="innerFlex-R9N_u"><svg viewBox="0 0 24 24" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" role="presentation" class="sc-1d18oav-0 bYvpFK"> <path fill="currentColor" d="M20 4.75L19.25 4v16l.75-.75H4l.75.75V4L4 4.75h16zM3.25 4v16c0 .414.336.75.75.75h16a.75.75 0 0 0 .75-.75V4a.75.75 0 0 0-.75-.75H4a.75.75 0 0 0-.75.75zm11.07 8.888c.23-.357.606-.353.828-.008l2.887 4.482c.227.352.06.638-.357.638H6.326c-.421 0-.581-.3-.37-.648l4.006-6.622c.217-.358.567-.359.793.014l2.396 3.96 1.17-1.816zm1.59-2.735c1.14 0 2.066-.907 2.066-2.026 0-1.12-.926-2.027-2.067-2.027s-2.066.907-2.066 2.027c0 1.119.925 2.026 2.066 2.026z"> </path></svg><div class="description-Rip0y"><div class="sc-1szn76m-0 cRcVWO i18nString-raclU">Image</div><div class="sc-1szn76m-0 cRcVWO title-RrK9J">Elder and Sister Rasband in Thailand.</div></div></div></div></figure></div></div>
<p data-aid="159163277" id="p25">Last October my wife, Melanie, and I were in Bangkok, Thailand, as I was preparing to dedicate what would be the Church’s 185th temple.<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/41rasband?lang=eng#note23" data-scroll-id="note23"><sup class="marker" data-value="23"></sup></a> For me, the assignment was both surreal and humbling. This was the first temple on the Southeast Asia peninsula.<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/41rasband?lang=eng#note24" data-scroll-id="note24"><sup class="marker" data-value="24"></sup></a> It was masterfully designed—a six-story, nine-spired structure, “fitly framed”<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/41rasband?lang=eng#note25" data-scroll-id="note25"><sup class="marker" data-value="25"></sup></a> to be a house of the Lord. For months I had contemplated the dedication. What had settled in my soul and mind was that the country and the temple had been cradled in the arms of prophets and apostles. President Thomas S. Monson had announced the temple<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/41rasband?lang=eng#note26" data-scroll-id="note26"><sup class="marker" data-value="26"></sup></a> and President Nelson the dedication.<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/41rasband?lang=eng#note27" data-scroll-id="note27"><sup class="marker" data-value="27"></sup></a></p>
<div><div class="imageWrapper-wTPPD"><figure class="imageWithModal-ILaMF loadImageItem-u5D4D" title="Bangkok Thailand Temple."><img width="500" height="281" alt=""/><div class="container-W4jed"><div class="innerFlex-R9N_u"><svg viewBox="0 0 24 24" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" role="presentation" class="sc-1d18oav-0 bYvpFK"> <path fill="currentColor" d="M20 4.75L19.25 4v16l.75-.75H4l.75.75V4L4 4.75h16zM3.25 4v16c0 .414.336.75.75.75h16a.75.75 0 0 0 .75-.75V4a.75.75 0 0 0-.75-.75H4a.75.75 0 0 0-.75.75zm11.07 8.888c.23-.357.606-.353.828-.008l2.887 4.482c.227.352.06.638-.357.638H6.326c-.421 0-.581-.3-.37-.648l4.006-6.622c.217-.358.567-.359.793.014l2.396 3.96 1.17-1.816zm1.59-2.735c1.14 0 2.066-.907 2.066-2.026 0-1.12-.926-2.027-2.067-2.027s-2.066.907-2.066 2.027c0 1.119.925 2.026 2.066 2.026z"> </path></svg><div class="description-Rip0y"><div class="sc-1szn76m-0 cRcVWO i18nString-raclU">Image</div><div class="sc-1szn76m-0 cRcVWO title-RrK9J">Bangkok Thailand Temple.</div></div></div></div></figure></div></div>
<p data-aid="159163283" id="p26">I had prepared the dedicatory prayer months earlier. Those sacred words had been translated into 12 languages. We were ready. Or so I thought.</p>
<p data-aid="159163289" id="p27">The night before the dedication, I was awakened from my sleep with an unsettled, urgent feeling about the dedicatory prayer. I tried to set aside the prompting, thinking the prayer was in place. But the Spirit would not leave me alone. I sensed certain words were missing, and by divine design they came to me in revelation, and <span class="page-break" data-page="76"></span>I inserted these words in the prayer near the end: “May we think celestial, letting Thy Spirit prevail in our lives, and strive to be peacemakers always.”<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/41rasband?lang=eng#note28" data-scroll-id="note28"><sup class="marker" data-value="28"></sup></a> The Lord was reminding me to heed the words of our living prophet: “Think celestial,” “let the Spirit prevail,” “strive to be peacemakers.” Words of the prophet matter to the Lord and to us.</p>
<p data-aid="159163297" id="p28">Third, and so very important, are our own words. Believe me, in our emoji-filled<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/41rasband?lang=eng#note29" data-scroll-id="note29"><sup class="marker" data-value="29"></sup></a> world, our words matter.</p>
<p data-aid="159163302" id="p29">Our words can be supportive or angry, joyful or mean, compassionate or tossed aside. In the heat of the moment, words can sting and sink painfully deep into the soul—and stay there. Our words on the internet, texting, social media, or tweets take on a life of their own. So be careful what you say and how you say it. In our families, especially with husbands, wives, and children, our words can bring us together or drive a wedge between us.</p>
<p data-aid="159163309" id="p30">Let me suggest three simple phrases that we can use to take the sting out of difficulties and differences, lift, and reassure each other:</p>
<p data-aid="159163314" id="p31">“Thank you.”</p>
<p data-aid="159163320" id="p32">“I am sorry.”</p>
<p data-aid="159163325" id="p33">And “I love you.”</p>
<p data-aid="159163328" id="p35">Do not save these humble phrases for a special event or catastrophe. Use them often and sincerely, for they show regard for others. Talk is growing cheap; do not follow that pattern.</p>
<p data-aid="159163331" id="p36">We can say “thank you” on the elevator, in the parking lot, at the market, in the office, in a queue, or with our neighbors or friends. We can say “I am sorry” when we make a mistake, miss a meeting, forget a birthday, or see someone in pain. We can say “I love you,” and those words carry the message “I am thinking about you,” “I care about you,” “I am here for you,” or “You are everything to me.”</p>
<p data-aid="159163337" id="p37">Let me share a personal example. Husbands, take heed. Sisters, this is going to help you too. Before my full-time assignment in the Church, I traveled widely for my company. I was gone a fair amount of time to far reaches of the world. At the end of my day, no matter where I was, I always called home. When my wife, Melanie, picked up the phone and I reported in, our conversation always led us to expressing “I love you.” Every day, those words served as an anchor to my soul and my conduct; they were a protection to me from evil designs. “Melanie, I love you” spoke of the precious trust between us.</p>
<p data-aid="159163345" id="p38">President Thomas S. Monson used to say, “There are feet to steady, hands to grasp, minds to encourage, hearts to inspire, and souls to save.”<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/41rasband?lang=eng#note30" data-scroll-id="note30"><sup class="marker" data-value="30"></sup></a> Saying “thank you,” “I am sorry,” “I love you” will do just that.</p>
<p data-aid="159163351" id="p39">Brothers and sisters, words do matter.</p>
<p data-aid="159163357" id="p40">I promise that if we “feast upon the words of Christ”<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/41rasband?lang=eng#note31" data-scroll-id="note31"><sup class="marker" data-value="31"></sup></a> that lead to salvation, our prophet’s words that guide and encourage us, and our own words that speak of who we are and what we hold dear, the powers of heaven will pour down upon us. “The words of Christ will tell you all things what ye should do.”<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/41rasband?lang=eng#note32" data-scroll-id="note32"><sup class="marker" data-value="32"></sup></a> We are Heavenly Father’s children and He is our God, and He expects us to speak with “the tongue of angels”<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/41rasband?lang=eng#note33" data-scroll-id="note33"><sup class="marker" data-value="33"></sup></a> by the power of the Holy Ghost.<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/41rasband?lang=eng#note34" data-scroll-id="note34"><sup class="marker" data-value="34"></sup></a></p>
<p data-aid="159163365" id="p41">I love the Lord Jesus Christ. He is, in the words of the Old Testament prophet Isaiah, “Wonderful, Counsellor, The mighty God, The everlasting Father, The Prince of Peace.”<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/41rasband?lang=eng#note35" data-scroll-id="note35"><sup class="marker" data-value="35"></sup></a> And as the Apostle John made clear, Jesus Christ Himself is “the Word.”<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/41rasband?lang=eng#note36" data-scroll-id="note36"><sup class="marker" data-value="36"></sup></a></p>
<p data-aid="159163373" id="p42">Of this I testify as an Apostle called to the Lord’s divine service—to declare His word—and called to stand as a special witness of Him. In the name of the Lord Jesus Christ, amen.</p>
</div>
